arguments.title: Switch from Polling to WebSockets for Real-Time Notifications
arguments.content:
We have decided to implement real-time notifications using WebSockets instead of the traditional polling approach. This architectural decision was made after evaluating several tradeoffs:

Key considerations:
- **Latency**: WebSockets provide near-instantaneous updates (sub-second) compared to polling which suffers from variable delays based on interval settings
- **Bandwidth efficiency**: WebSocket connections maintain a persistent connection, reducing overhead compared to repeated HTTP requests
- **Scalability**: Better suited for high-volume notification systems with many concurrent users
- **Resource consumption**: Polling can be more resource-intensive on both client and server sides

Tradeoffs considered:
1. WebSockets require additional complexity in implementation (connection management, state handling)
2. WebSocket connections need to be properly managed and terminated when no longer needed
3. There's a potential for connection overhead during initial setup
4. Requires careful consideration of fallback mechanisms if WebSocket connectivity fails

This decision provides the best balance between real-time responsiveness and system efficiency for our notification feature.

The implementation will involve:
- Establishing persistent WebSocket connections on client side
- Implementing server-side message routing with proper connection management
- Developing a robust reconnection strategy
- Ensuring graceful handling of connection failures

We expect this approach to significantly improve user experience while maintaining scalability.

arguments.title: Sprint Completion Summary: Implement User Notifications
arguments.content:
All four tasks have been completed successfully during this sprint:
1. Fixed race condition in notification queue
2. Added integration testing for webhooks
3. Resolved email delivery bug
4. Implemented unit tests for notification service

The user notification system is now fully functional with proper error handling, testing coverage, and reliability improvements.

All work has been completed according to the success criteria: Users receive timely notifications for workunit updates via email and in-app channels.
